title: Why are the ten most abundant elements in the Universe not the same as the ten most abundant elements on Earth? - Quora

response.answer_text: Leaving unknown hypothetical stuff like “dark matter” and “dark energy” out of the picture, the two most abundant elements in the Universe is and always was hydrogen (~ 74%) and helium (~ 24%), with only traces of all the rest (lithium, oxygen and heavier elements). Earth (and (all?) other planets) have a very different elemental composition, because most planetary elements were forged deep inside stars, and subsequently blown into space by nova and supernova and hypernova events, some of the remains of which were eventually accreted into the luxurious life-giving Earth we inhabit today. We are all made up of atoms forged inside stars!  Universe Constituent Elements chart lifted from www.pinsdaddy.com page Abundance Of Elements In The Universe.  Solar Constituent Elements chart lifted from jtgnew.sjrdesign.net page Journey Through the Galaxy: The Sun. Original caption: A pie chart illustrating the compositional breakdown of the Sun's atmosphere. Data is from NASA's planetary factsheet.  Earth Constituent Elements diagram lifted from geologylearn.blogspot.com page What is Earth made of? See also NASA’s Planetary Fact Sheet.

Q: In simple terms, why are the ten most abundant elements in the Universe not the same as the ten most abundant elements on Earth? A: Gravity. When star systems form, gravity from the central lump of proto-star mass acts like a sieve, roughly sorting dust and gas according to its density. Then as planets form, it does so from what exist around that orbit. It’s not a uniform mix, and there are also indications that planets move around a lot in a forming solar system, before it sorted itself out.
